A sequence $(a_n)$ is defined as follows:
\[a_{i + 1} = \frac{1}{1 - a_i}\]for $i \ge 1.$  If $a_3 = a_1,$ compute $(a_9)^9.$

direct_answer.text: We know that $a_3 = a_1$, so let us consider what happens when it comes time to calculate $a_4$: \[a_4 = f(a_3) = \frac{1}{1 - a_3} = \frac{1}{1 - a_1}.\]Similarly \[\begin{aligned} a_5 &=f(a_4) = \frac{1}{1-a_4} \\&= \frac{1}{\left(\frac{1}{1-a_1}\right)} \\&= 1-a_1\\ &=a_2 .\end{aligned}\]So every other term repeats itself likewise! It turns out quite easily enough now knowing how quickly things go back around once reached maximum size/value compared earlier found above; therefore taking into account just nine iterations would mean having gone round twice
